Dear Ms. Moffett:
Attached is the Special Investigation Report for the above referenced facility. Due to the
violations identified in the report, a written corrective action plan is required. The
corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter and must include the
following:
• How compliance with each rule will be achieved.
• For any repeat violations, why the prior corrective action plan did not result
in compliance.
• Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action for each
violation.
• Specific time frames for each violation as to when the correction will be
completed or implemented.
• Indicate how continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
• Be signed and dated.
A six-month provisional license is recommended. If you do not contest the issuance of a
provisional license, you must indicate so in writing; this may be included in your corrective
action plan or in a separate document. If you contest the issuance of a provisional license,
you must notify this office in writing and an administrative hearing will be scheduled. Even
if you contest the issuance of a provisional license, you must still submit an acceptable
corrective action plan.
Please note that violations of any licensing rules are also violations of the MISEP and
your contract.

ALLEGATION:
The agency is not financially stable.
INVESTIGATION:
Chief Administrator X was interviewed virtually via a Teams meeting on 2/3/2022 by
Area Manager T and I. We discussed financial concerns for the agency as
documented/outlined by the Michigan Department of Health and Human Services
(MDHSS) Audit and Review Section’s reviews of Homes for Black Children’s (HBC)
fiscal year 12/31/2017 to 2020.
Chief Administrator X reported HBC addressed the concerns related to the
Department’s audit of HBC’s Foster Care Program and Cost Reporting for
10/01/2016, through 12/31/2018 via a corrective action plan. She reported the plan
they put forth indicated they would have a reserve. She reported a part of the plan
was to increase their child placement numbers. She said the agency is looking to
hire two more foster care workers to enable an increase in placement numbers. She
said, they are no longer worried about whether they can pay payroll; that the
agency’s finances are getting better. She expressed concerns that the department is
not taking the corrective action HBC submitted into consideration. She reported it
was true the agency owed funds to the department, due to overpayments; but those
funds were repaid. She reported the funds were reimbursed to MDHHS by way of
the state recouping the owed funds from foster care and adoption payments due to
the agency. Chief Administrator X reported if she felt it was not possible to improve
the agency’s financial stability, she would say so.
Chief Administrator X reported the agency is current with its lease, utilities, taxes,
and other agency financial obligations. Chief Administrator X was asked to provide
proof of being current with these obligations, however she failed to do so. On
3/9/2022 she provided a “Homes for Black Children Financial Instability Complaint”
letter and other documents to show that the agency was doing better financially with
respect to what the Department had reported related to the agency’s finances.
Below is a summary of the Homes for Black Children Financial Instability Complaint
letter, and the “Homes for Black Children’s Notes to Financial Statements
(Continued) for the Years Ended December 31,2020 and 2019”, page 11, submitted
by Chief Administrator X:
Homes for Black Children Financial Instability Complaint Letter (authored by
the chief administrator);
This letter is signed by Chief Administrator X as the president, and indicated:
• On March 17, 2021, HBC submitted a corrective action plan to the Auditor
General’s office regarding its 2017 and 2018 onsite audit findings.
• In advance of the Auditor General’s findings HBC had made considerable
progress toward solution of the stated concerns in the listed areas. The
following was a summary of the those submitted responses:
5

➢ Eliminated all non-essential positions, and reduced salary expenses by
approximately $85,000.
➢ Created a reserve fund equal to one month’s expenses to cover cash flow
during the services rendered and services paid cycle.
➢ Eliminated voluntary loans from staff to cover cash flow.
➢ Reduced overpayments to the State of Michigan by $37,000.
➢ Remaining current on all foster care payments.
➢ Eliminated excessive legal and bank fees.
➢ Elimination of Independent audit delays. The 2019-18 audit was submitted
prior to the due date.
➢ Reorganization of accounting system.
➢ As of 3/9/2022 HBC continues to make progress in assuring it’s financial
stability.
• HBC continues to make progress and remains compliant in the following
areas of financial stability:
➢ All Foster Care payments to Foster Families remain current.
➢ Staff salaries, federal and state deposits remain current.
➢ The overpayment to the State of $138,629.10 has been repaid; the
agency overpaid and is due a refund in the amount of $7,072.15.
➢ Despite considerable lags between services rendered and services paid,
at the closing of the agency’s financial records for the calendar year 2021,
HBC had a net income(surplus) of $72,486.24
➢ HBC’s audit requirement for 2020-19 was submitted prior to the due date.
• A reference to Note H, page 11 from its financial statement for the year end
12/31/2020 and 2019 regarding on-going concern. It quoted this section of
that page which spoke to management’s institution of a cost reduction
program, that includes a reduction in labor cost. Additionally, that the agency
had instituted more efficient management techniques and it was believed
those factors would contribute toward agency profitability.
Home for Black Children’s Notes to Financial Statements for the Years Ended
December 31,2020 and 2019, submitted by Chief administrator:
• This page is titled “Note H- Going Concern Issues Arising from Deficits in Net
Assets and Cash Flow Problems.
• The information on this page stated “As shown in the accompanying financial
statements the organization had a deficit in net assets in the amount of $906,753
as of December 31, 2020, and $732,939 as of December 31,2019. Its current
liabilities exceeded its current assets in the amount of $922,660 as of December
31,2020 and $789,664 as of December 31, 2019. These factors raise substantial
doubt about the Organizations’ ability to continue as a going concern.
Management has instituted a cost reduction program that included a reduction in
labor cost. In addition, the Organization has instituted more efficient management
techniques. Management believes these factors will contribute toward achieving
6

profitability. The accompanying financial statements do not include any
adjustments that might be necessary if the organization is unable to continue as
a going concern. Funding was impacted by a reduction in services related to
COVID-19 Pandemic Crisis.”
Chief Administrator X also provided copies of:
• HBC’s 2021 Sales, Use and Withholding Taxes Annual Return; and form 941
Employer’s Quarterly Federal Tax Returns for 2021(January- March; April –
June; July -September; October-December) and 2020(July-September) showing
its wages, tips and other compensations, total deposits and refundable credits;
and total taxes after adjustments. These totals ranged between $126,742.88 and
$138,100.09 related to wages/compensations: and $34,452.67 to $39,9 44.77 for
total taxes/adjustments. The significance of these documents with respect to
HBC’s financial stability is not clear to me.
• HBC’s schedule of payments for over payment to the Department, showing
check payments to the Department from 7/24/2020 to 12/7/2021. Also, the
State’s interception of payments from the agency for 12/24/2020; 12/16/2021;
1/3/2022 and 1/19/2022. The schedule showed a $7,072.15 balance due.
• Pages 1- 3 of an HBC “Profit & Loss January through December 2021 document.
It was not indicated where or from what report these pages are from. The pages
showed:
➢ $754, 708.37 Foster Care Income from the State of Michigan.
➢ $69, 592.39 from Counseling Unit income; and other income from PPP
Loan Grant- Part #2, Insurance claim.
➢ Other income as $1,016,783.02. It showed, after salaries, taxes, fringe
benefits, office, and administrative costs, the had a net Income of $72,
486.24.
• A voucher/warrant showing four payments to HBC: (12/16/2021,
12/24/2021,12/30/2021,1/19/2022) for $62,360.40.
In addition to the documents provided by Chief Administrator X, I reviewed a MDHHS
Bureau of Audit Division Foster Care Program Audit for HBC for the period October 1,
2016- September 30, 2018, which was issued and provided to HBC on 4/30/2021; a
March 4, 2021, and February 4, 2022, Memorandum from the MDHHS Audit Division;
and HBC’s 2021 Statement of Activities Operation budget for 2021. I also reviewed an
email statement from the MDHHS Financial Audit Manager of his review of the 3/9/2022
documents HBC provided for this investigation. Below is a summary of the content of
those documents; and the MDHHS Financial Audit Manager’s email statement:
Foster Care Program Audit the period October 1, 2016- September 30, 2018:
This audit documented six “Exceptions” (financial concerns); recommendations; and the
agency’s comments and proposed corrective action plan for the specific exception
indicated. The specific exception/concern and the corrective action plan indicated by
HBC is listed below:
7

Exception 1-Lack of Fiscal Stability and timely audit completion and reporting:
This exception indicated: During the reporting period (2016-2018) three of the four
prior financial audits were not within required timeframes. Additionally, the
independent auditor issued a going concern opinion for the four prior audits (2016-
2019). “A going concern opinion indicates the independent auditor believes there is
substantial doubt the entity will be able to continue in the future.”
• 2016 audit was 2 years past due; total liabilities exceeded total assets by
$1,091,359.
• 2017 audit was 1 year past due; total liabilities exceeded total assets by
$1,178.534.
• 2018 audit was 1 year past due; total liabilities exceeded total assets by $635,
372.
• 2019 total liabilities exceeded total assets by $732,939.
• Accounting irregularities in the form of undocumented employee to employer
loans were identified totaling $52,773 to cover cash short fall during 2017 and
2018. This practice was denoted as financially risky for both parties and
exposed the agency to additionally liabilities.
• During the review it was noted that in 2018 HBC incurred $43,534 for bank
fees and penalties; $41,642 for tax resolution and preparation; $1,475 for
bank overdrafts fees; and $417 for insufficient funds/returned item fees.
HBC’s Corrective Action Plan to Exception 1 to be completed by 4/26/2021 was that:
The agency would discontinue accepting staff loans. Cash flow concerns had been
mitigated by development of a reserve fund. An overall reduction in wages and
salaries would be utilized to reduce overall operating loss. The agency anticipated
an increase in agency revenue, after the pandemic, via fund raising and purchase of
service contracts.
Exception 2- Reported Salaries and Wages Exceed Amounts Paid:
This exception indicated: The costs reported for salaries were greater than actual
expenditures in the financial accounting system and resulted in an overstatement of
reported direct expenses by $122,183, This resulted in unallowed costs reported to
MDHHS on the CPA’s fiscal year (FY)17 Cost Report.
HBC’s Corrective Action Plan to Exception 2 to be completed by 4/26/2021 was that:
All data collected for the preparation of the cost report would be the responsibility of
the agency’s accountant. All outstanding checks would be voided and canceled after
90-days of authorization. Program managers of each department will validate the
authenticity of the information, and the Chief Executive Officer, along with the
leadership team (Accountant, Foster Care Program Manager and Resources
Program Manager) will review the report before its submission.
Exception 3-Payments to Foster Care Families Not Made in Timely Fashion:
This exception indicated: During the review the auditor noted HBC did not pay foster
care families for services in a timely fashion. Seven out of 28 (25%) sample
8

payments showed foster families were paid six months or later after the initiation of
services. Two of the 28 were paid more than one year after services were initiated.
Contact was attempted with 22 foster families. Contact was made with 10 (45%)
who reported HBC was up to date on their payments. Timely payment to the other
12 foster families was unable to be verified.
HBC’s Corrective Action Plan to Exception 3 to be completed by 4/30/2021 was that:
The agency commented that all payment were current. That a one-month reserve
has been created to assure timely foster parent board and care payments.
Exception 4- Foster Care Board and Care Expense Reported in Wrong Year:
This exception indicated: During the review 11 of 28 (39%) Foster Care Board and
Care expenses selected for testing were incurred prior to FY18 but payments were
recorded in FY18 and reported on the FY18 cost report. This audit found that
$29,353 was reported on the FY18 report when it should have been reported in
years prior to FY18.
HBC’s Corrective Action Plan to Exception 4 to be completed by 11/30/2020 was
that:
The accountant would be responsible for preparing the cost report. The accountant
has received additional training in cost reporting and will review the State of
Michigan Cost Report training manual prior to preparation of the report. The
Program Manager of each department will validate the authenticity of the
information, and the Chief Executive Officer, along with the leadership team will
review the report before its submission.
Exception 5- Foster Care Board and Care Payments Not Made:
This exception indicated: Of the 28 payments to foster families in FY18 reported on
the agency’s cost report as expenses, there was no evidence that eight (29%) of the
checks, $37,301, were cashed; per review of the agency’s FY18 bank statements.
Also, a check stub of one of the eight payments showed a 10/13/2019 issuance
date, which was after the audit work commenced. HBC reported that check should
have been voided.
HBC’s Corrective Action Plan to Exception 5 to be completed by 6/28/2020 was that:
MISACWIS information would determine which family is to be paid for foster board
and care each month.
Exception 6- Documentation Related to Service Dates Did Not Reconcile with
MDHHS Records:
This exception indicated: During the review it was noted that HBC provided
documentation related to service dates on four of eight (50%) payments to foster
families that did not reconcile to the service dates recorded in MISACWIS. On one
occasion the documentation showed service dates from 4/1/2017 until 11/30/2017.
However, MISACWIS showed the services dates did not start until 9/29/2018. In the
other three instances, HBC showed service dates taking place during FY18, while
9

MISACWIS detailed service dates occurring prior to FY18, with services as early as
FY12. This resulted in HBC including costs incurred outside of the required
reporting period on the FY18 Cost Report
HBC’s Corrective Action Plan to Exception 6 to be completed by 12/31/2020 was
that:
All foster care census and payment authorization data would be obtained through
MIASCWIS and reconciled to agency records by the accountant. Monthly census
data would be provided to the accountant.
This Foster Care Program Audit for October 1, 2016- September 30, 2018
recommended that HBC implement an adequate internal control system over financial
reporting that provides reasonable assurance that financial reports are supported by
accounting records.
March 4, 2021, and February 4, 2022, Memorandums from the MDHHS Audit

MDHHS Financial Audit Manager’s review of the 3/9/2022 documents provided
by HBC:
The Financial Audit Manager indicated the package of information does not
constitute an independent financial statement audit. Additionally, that it showed
“they are making progress with a $72k surplus for 2021 activity; but from reading
“Note H” from the 2020 audit which they included in the package, the auditor still
classified HBC as a “going concern” and notes that they have substantial debt
greater than $900k.” That “a quick and simple assumption based on the information
they provided would be that HBC didn’t take on any additional liabilities in 2021, and
the best case is they would reduce their overall debt by that $72k surplus. However,
they would still owe roughly $850k. If that is the case, I fully anticipate an
independent audit would classify HBC as a going concern, again. Unfortunately, a
large deficit and classification as a going concern does not indicate good financial
standing.”
During this investigation, between 3/18/2022 and 3/21/2022, I also spoke with four
agency staff persons (Staff 1- 4, one of whom was Agency Accountant XX), and four
foster parent/caregivers (Foster Parent/Caregiver A-D). All four employees reported
being paid by the agency via check every two weeks. Neither employee reported
ever having an agency paycheck to be late or to bounce. Nor had they ever not
received a paycheck. One employee reported a knowledge of past financial issues
for the agency but reported that was three or four years ago. This employee also
acknowledged they had received calls from a couple of caregivers inquiring about
their board and care payments, but that was one to two years ago.
Staff 4/Agency Accountant XX also acknowledged the agency had experienced
financial woes across the board with paying its accounts about four years ago. The
accountant reported the agency has been getting better financially with incomes and
revenues over the last one to two years. He reported the agency is current on all its
financial obligations; that there are no deficits at this time. He reported one concern
is that MDHHS is still paying slowly. He reported the agency has borrowed from
banks from time to time; and took out a small business loan, due to COVID/ to avoid
12

laying off staff, but have not had to take any loans of late. He reported no current
financial concerns related to the agency’s financial status. He reported the agency
as having a $72,000 surplus at the end of last year. He anticipates a large surplus
this year. But despite the surplus they will still be in substantial debt.
Of the four-foster parents/caregivers interviewed, all reported being paid in the
current month for the past month’s care to the foster child. Neither reported any late,
missed, or bounced foster care payment checks. Neither of these foster
parents/caregivers had concerns about the agency being able to pay. Only one of
these foster parents/caregivers had heard of possible agency financial problems.
This foster parent/caregiver reported hearing from a friend, who was a former
agency foster parent, that the agency does not pay timely. That prior foster parent
had stated, “you’ll never get your money”; but this foster parent/caregiver stated,
“they never did that me”, meaning the agency had paid them their funds.
After initial completion of this report additional information was received from
the agency and assessed to better understand and clarify financial information
they reported.
On 6/2/2022 the following information was received:
Chief Administrator X was asked to clarify:
a. The root cause of the huge difference between the agency’s assets and
liabilities. To provide an explanation of this difference, how it occurred,
which respect to looking at how this may prevent future occurrence.
b. What is the concrete plan to bring down the liabilities? What will the
agency do with its reported $72k surplus at the end of 2021. Will all, some,
most of it be used to pay down debt?.
c. Are there other sources of revenue HBC plans to get to pay down the
agency’s debts? If so, how quickly will that occur?
d. What is the agency’s total debts/ liabilities owed in 2020; 2021 and now?
Chief Administrator X did not exactly address each point, but reported the following
related to these questions:
• Cost saving measures, were instituted as the independent auditor
referenced in his report Note G.
• In 2020, the agency restructured by:
1. Eliminating all non-essential staff (secretarial, administrative, etc.)-
{To what number Chief Administrator X did not report}.
2. Reducing employee benefits. {To what degree Chief Administrator
X did not report}.
3. Eliminating non-MDHHS funded support programs (e.g., agency
funded life enrichment activities, agency funded parent partner and
mentoring programs). Previously these programs were funded
through time limited grants and reduction in support from United
Way.
13

4. Restructuring the adoption program by reducing adoption goals and
elimination of the adoption parent support program. For many
years HBC’s adoption program was not cost neutral and over the
years created a liability. This was a significant factor in the
accumulation of a deficit.
5. Decreasing operational expenses. {To what degree Chief

APPLICABLE RULE
R 400.12202 Policy and procedures.
An agency shall have and follow written policies and procedures
for all of the following:
(a)Financial stability.
20

ANALYSIS: From 2017 to 2020 HBC continued to experience financial
deficits in revenue. At the 2019 year end it was ($97,567); and
2020-year end ($86,908). The agency experienced a net
income/ surplus of $72,486.24 at the end of 2021, but there is
some question as to whether that surplus is a realistic net
income when off-set by what may be owed by the agency. To
that end, financial stability concerns continue. It should be noted
here they are $900k in debt despite these year-end numbers.
In 2020 the agency restructured and instituted various cost
saving measures to reduce its liabilities. It made reductions in
its liabilities by $6,603 in 2020; and $55,021 in 2021.
Notwithstanding those annual reductions, the agency reports a
continued liability of $561,380 as of 2021.
Additionally, information provided by the agency showed the
agency owed back lease payments in the amount of $20,000; a
$149,000- $150,000 small business loan, other expenses that
are unable to be clearly assessed; and the old debt impact as
referenced above.
The agency has demonstrated progress toward some
enhancements in their accounting practices and has established
a plan to improve their financial stability as outlined in the
commitments made to the Department. There remains,
however, incomplete action toward completion of those
commitments established to remedy the concerns noted in this
investigation.
Based on the ongoing concerns expressed in the audits and
continued deficit liabilities issues, the agency does not
demonstrate financial stability as required by this rule.
CONCLUSION: VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
IV. RECOMMENDATION
Up receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan modification of the license to a first
provisional license is recommended.
